metadata.title: Nutritional impact of nano-selenium, garlic oil, and their combination on growth and reproductive performance of male Californian rabbits

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Animal Feed Science and Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/anifeedsci
Nutritional impact of nano-selenium, garlic oil, and their combination on growth and reproductive performance of male Californian rabbits
A.A.A. Abdel-Waretha, A.E. Ahmedb,c, H.A. Hassana, M.S. Abd El-Sadekd,e, A.A. Ghazalahf, J. Lohakareg,⁎
aDepartment of Animal and Poultry Production, Faculty of Agriculture, South Valley University, 83523, Qena, Egypt bDepartment of Biology, Faculty of Science, King Khalid University, 61413, Abha, Saudi Arabia cDepartment of Theriogenology, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, South Valley University, 83523, Qena, Egypt dNanomaterials Lab., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, South Valley University, 83523, Qena, Egypt e Egypt Nanotechnology Center (EGNC), Cairo University, El-Sheikh Zayed Campus, Egypt fDepartment of Animal Production, Faculty of Agriculture, Cairo University, 12613, Giza, Egypt gDepartment of Agriculture - Animal Science, University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, Pine Bluff, AR, 71601, USA
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanotechnology Reproductive performance Nutrient digestibility Liver function Male rabbits
A B S T R A C T
This study aimed to investigate the effects of nano-selenium (nano-Se), garlic oil, and their combination on nutrients digestibility, semen quality, serum testosterone and metabolites of male Californian rabbits. A total of 80 rabbits (120 days of age) were randomly distributed into four treatment groups of 20 rabbits each. Treatment groups were fed a control diet, a control diet supplemented with nano-Se (400 μg/kg), control diet supplemented with garlic oil (700mg/kg), or control diet supplemented with combination of nano-Se (400 μg/kg) and garlic oil (700mg/ kg). The feeding trial lasted for 60 days. The results showed that improvements were observed in body weight (BW) gain and feed conversion ratio (FCR) in nano-Se treated group than nonsupplemented group, and an interaction effect was observed on final BW of rabbits. The digestibility of all measured nutrients were significantly higher (P < 0.01) for animals fed nanoSe, garlic oil, and the combination group compared to their non-supplemented counterparts. Furthermore, semen characteristics were significantly improved (P < 0.01) in nano-Se and garlic oil supplemented groups compared to non-supplemented groups. Likewise, supplementation of nano-Se, garlic oil, and their combination significantly improved liver and kidney functions as indicated from serum metabolites, and increased serum testosterone hormone levels. Therefore, it can be concluded that nano-Se or garlic oil and their combination improved the nutrients digestibility, semen quality, kidney and liver functions, and testosterone levels in male rabbits.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.anifeedsci.2019.01.016 Received 17 April 2018; Received in revised form 4 January 2019; Accepted 28 January 2019
Abbreviations: nano-Se, nano-selenium; BW, body weight; FCR, feed conversion ratio; AST, aspartate transaminase; ALT, alanine transaminase; BUN, blood urea nitrogen; DM, dry matter; OM, organic matter; CP, crude protein; EE, ether extract; CF, crude fiber
⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Agriculture - Animal Science, University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, Pine Bluff, AR, 71601, USA. E-mail address: lohakarej@uapb.edu (J. Lohakare).
Animal Feed Science and Technology 249 (2019) 37–45
0377-8401/ Published by Elsevier B.V.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In North African countries rabbit industry has developed rapidly, and applied research on vital aspects of rabbit production such as economics, housing, management, nutrition and reproduction is urgently needed to ensure a high success rate of rabbit development, which could have a favorable economic and nutritional impact (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2015; Al-Sagheer et al., 2017).
With the use of nanotechnology, nanoparticles can be used as a supplemental source of trace minerals in the diets which have been found to have several novel properties different to those from bulk materials or commercial salts of these minerals (Mohapatra et al., 2014). Dietary selenium is an essential trace element for animal growth, fertility, hormones, physiological parameters and metabolism as well as external and internal organs (Mohapatra et al., 2014; Surai, 2006). Selenium can be supplemented in the form of organic, inorganic, and nanoparticles; however, nanoparticles of selenium possess comparable efficiency, high bioavailability, high catalytic efficiency, strong adsorbing ability, and low toxicity compared with other selenium sources (Wang et al., 2009). Selenium improves the productive performance and antioxidant status of animals, particularly in hot summer environments (Mahima et al., 2012).
The feed additives like nanoparticles of trace minerals, herbal plants, essential oils, probiotics, and enzymes play an active role in productive and reproductive performance of domestic animals (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Abdel-Wareth and Lohakare, 2014; Ashour et al., 2014). Since ancient times, garlic (Allium sativum L.) has been used to cure diseases. The first citation of medical application of garlic as a remedy is found in the Codex Ebers (1550 BCE), an Egyptian medical papyrus (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Supplementation of garlic oil at 0.5 g/kg of diet has a positive effect on testes weight, antioxidant status, and testosterone hormone in rabbits (El-Gogary et al., 2017). Alagawany et al. (2016) reported that garlic improved the immunity responses and lowered the lipid profile in blood, lipid peroxidation in liver, and increased hepatic antioxidant activity in treated rabbits. The major bioactive components in garlic such as Allicin are mainly responsible for the positive effects of garlic (Santhosha et al., 2013). Productive and reproductive performances as well as physiological parameters were improved significantly by addition of garlic powder to rabbit diet (Onu and Aja, 2011). Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increase observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium level could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits.
The selenium levels in the rabbit diets vary widely according to dietary ingredients and selenium supplementation, ranging from 0.05 to 0.4mg/kg in non-supplemented to about 1mg with a supplementation of 0.6 mg selenium yeast or 0.6 mg sodium selenite/kg diet (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016; Amer et al., 2018; De Blas and Mateos, 2010; NRC, 1977; Saleh et al., 2013; Strucklec et al., 1994; Zhang et al., 2011). However, commercial premixes without supplemental selenium have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Further studies are needed to determine the significance of selenium in male rabbit nutrition. Due to the selenium effect on the reproductive capacity of males, this study may contribute to increase the efficiency and productivity of the male rabbits. Also, essential oils from garlic may contribute to improve growth, fertility, hormones, physiological parameters and animal metabolism. More investigations are needed to justify the effects of nanoparticles of selenium, garlic oil and their combination on reproductive performance and nutrient digestibility of rabbits. Therefore, the objective of this study was to assess and compare the effects of either nano-selenium (nano-Se) or garlic oil and their combination on nutrient digestibility, semen quality, and testosterone and blood metabolites of male Californian rabbits.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text: The Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of University of South Valley University approved the experimental protocol used in this study.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental animals, design and management
sections.text:
Rabbits were housed under similar managerial, hygienic, and environmental conditions during the total experimental period of 60 days. Throughout the trial, the rabbits were handled according to the principles of the care of experimental animals (Lebas et al., 1984), and the experiment was approved by the Committee of Ethics of the Animal and Poultry Production Department of the South Valley University. During the experiment, rabbits were subjected to regular inspections for body condition and health. The assessments of body condition were carried out by touching the ribs, pelvis, and spine of the rabbits.
A completely randomized design was used for investigating effects of nano-Se, garlic oil and their combination. A total of 80 male Californian rabbits (average body weight 2062 ± 12 g, 120 days old) were randomly distributed into four treatment groups of 20 rabbits each. Treatment groups were fed a control diet (Table 1), a control diet supplemented with nano-Se (400 μg/kg), control diet supplemented with garlic oil (700mg/kg), or control diet supplemented with combination of nano-selenium (400 μg/kg) and garlic oil (700mg/kg). The diets were formulated according to the requirements of growing rabbit recommended by NRC (1977).
Ingredients, chemical composition and the energy value of the experimental diets are presented in Table 1. During the whole experiment, animals of all treatments received the pelleted diet for ad libitum consumption. First, Nano-Se, garlic oil or their combination were mixed separately in 2 kg of the basal diet each and then they were added to the required feed amount for the prescribed experimental period. The vitamin-mineral premix did not contain Se. Se content of the basal diet was analyzed (Agilent technologies, 8800 ICP-MS Triple Quad, Germany) and shown in Table 1.
The major components of garlic oil were extracted by Clevenger-type laboratory distillation according to Satyal et al. (2017). The main components of garlic oil were diallyl trisulfide (allitridin, 33%), diallyl disulfide (21%), allyl methyl trisulfide (19%), allyl (E)-1propenyl disulfide (5%), and allyl methyl disulfide (4%).
Rabbits were individually reared in metabolic cages (width× length× height: 44 cm×50 cm×35 cm) of galvanized wire net, equipped with an automatic drinker and a manual feeder. The rabbits were reared in an open house system (naturally ventilated room by windows and ceiling fans) with a 16 h light and 8 h dark regime during the whole experimental period. The average outdoor temperature and relative humidity during the experimental period were 36.0 °C and 26.2, respectively. The average brooding temperatures (indoors) and relative humidity were 35.2 °C and 28.6, respectively during the experimental period of 60 days. Fresh tap water was available for ad libitum consumption via stainless steel nipples located inside each cage. Weekly Body weight (BW) and feed intake (g/rabbit) were recorded during the entire experimental period. The feed conversion ratio (FCR) was calculated by dividing feed consumption by average BW gain. Signs of diarrhea were documented daily and mortality was recorded as it occurred.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-Se preparation
sections.text: Nano red elemental selenium (nano-Se) can be synthesized by reducing selenite in an environment containing bovine serum albumin (BSA) to the redox system of selenite and glutathione (GSH), the sizes of the nanoparticles are dependent on BSA concentration in the preparation system. One milliliter of 25mM sodium selenite was mixed with 4ml 25mM GSH containing BSA 40mg for the preparation of the nano-Se. BSA at higher concentration produces smaller nano-Se particles. The product was a pink powder with a measured Se 10–150 nm, and the median size was 80 nm. Limestone was used as a carrier to dilute the concentration of nanoSe to a suitable level for blending with the ration to achieve the desired level for diet formulation.

sections.heading: 2.3. Digestibility trial
sections.text:
At the end of the experiment, a digestibility trial was introduced which lasted for four days. Twenty rabbits within each treatment (n=20) were randomly individually housed in metabolic cages that allowed separation of faeces and urine. During the 4 days period, daily feed intake was determined and total faeces from each replicate were collected, weighed, and kept in a freezer at -10 °C until preparation for chemical analysis. Faecal samples were dried at 60 °C for 48 h (partial drying) before being analyzed. Samples of the feed and faeces were analyzed for moisture by oven drying (930.15), ash by incineration (942.05), protein by Kjeldahl (984.13), and ether extract by Soxhlet fat analysis (954.02), calcium (927.02) and phosphorous (935.59) as described by the AOAC International (2006). The gross energy was determined using adiabatic bomb calorimetry (Parr Instrument Company, IL, USA).
The digestibility of nutrients was calculated according to the following equation:
Digestibility, % = [(t-f)/t]100;
where, t is the nutrient intake during the collection period [g] and ƒ is the amount of nutrient excreted in faeces [g].

sections.heading: 2.4. Semen collection and evaluation
sections.text: As a biological material, semen quality (ejaculates) of sexually mature and healthy rabbits (180 days of age) of the male Californian breed were assessed as described by El-Desoky et al. (2017). Semen was collected from 20 animals (one ejaculate per animal) per treatment at the end of 60 days (experimental period). The ejaculates were collected using artificial vagina. The volume of each ejaculate was recorded using a graduated collection tube after removal of the gel mass. Assessment of live, dead, and abnormal sperm was performed by counting 200 sperm cells using an eosin–nigrosine blue staining mixture. Complete or partial purple-stained sperm cells were considered nonviable, whereas non-stained sperm cells were considered viable. The percentage of motile sperms (% of forward motility) was performed in several microscopic fields for semen sample by a visual examination under 100 × magnifications using a light microscope with heated stage and subjectively assessed from 0% to 100%.

sections.heading: 2.5. Blood parameters
sections.text: At the end of the experimental period, 10 representative rabbits from each treatment were subjected to anaesthesia by intramuscular injection of ketamine and xylazine, and then 10ml blood was withdrawn from ear vein of each rabbit. Serum was obtained by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 15min and the serum was harvested and stored at -20 ̊C until used in the biochemical assays. Serum testosterone concentrations were determined by immunoassay using commercial kits (Monobind Inc., Lake Forest; CA 92630, USA). Liver enzymes including aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT), as well as kidney function tests including urea, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) were determined using the standard diagnostic kits (Monobind Inc. Lake Forest; CA 92630, USA).

sections.heading: 2.6. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Statistical analysis of the data was performed using analysis of variance in a 2×2 factorial design that represents two main factors: nano-Se (with and without) and garlic oils (with and without). Data from the experiment was analyzed for the main effects of nano-Se, garlic oil, and the interaction between nano-Se and garlic oils using general linear model described in SAS/STAT® 9.1 User’s Guide (SAS Institute, 2009). Rabbits were the experimental units for all analyses. The square root transformation was used to normalize all data expressed as percentages. When an interaction effect was found the differences between treatments means were distinguished by Duncan’s multiple range test (Duncan, 1955). All statements of significance are based on P < 0.05 or P < 0.01, unless otherwise indicated.

sections.heading: 3.1. Productive performance
sections.text: Effects of nano-Se, garlic oil, or their combination on BW gain, feed intake and FCR are shown in Table 2. There was no mortality and the general health status of animals was good throughout the experimental period. Final BW and daily BW gain was significantly higher (P < 0.01) for animals fed nano-Se compared with the non-supplemented group. Feed intake was not affected significantly by the treatments, however, FCR was improved significantly for animals fed nano-Se when compared to non-supplemented group.

sections.heading: 3.2. Nutrient digestibility
sections.text:
Supplementation with nano-Se, garlic oil, or their combination showed effects on dry matter, organic matter, crude protein as well as crude fiber digestibility (Table 3) during the overall experimental period (120–180 days of age) of male Californian rabbits. The
Means are average of twenty replicates (n= 20 animals per treatment) during the experimental period (120–180 days of age). Nano-SE: Control with 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium, Garlic oil: Control with 700mg kg−1 garlic oil, nano-Se+Garlic oil: Control with combination of 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium+700mg kg−1 garlic oil. DBW gain: daily body weight gain, DFI: daily feed intake, DFCR: daily feed conversion ratio. SEM: Standard error of the means.
effects of nano-Se alone significantly (P < 0.01) increased dry matter, organic matter, crude protein and crude fiber digestibility, however, these effects of nano-Se were not significant (P≥ 0.05) on ether extract digestibility compared to non-supplemented group. Garlic oil supplementation alone resulted in an increase (P < 0.01) of dry matter, organic matter, crude protein, ether extract and crude fiber digestibility compared to non-supplemented group. Furthermore, significant (P < 0.01) interaction effects between nano-Se and garlic oil on dry matter, organic matter, crude protein, ether extract and crude fiber digestibility were also observed (Table 3).

sections.heading: 3.3. Semen quality
sections.text: In relation to semen quality (Table 4), dietary addition of nano-Se, garlic oil, or their combination to rabbits exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility at the end of the experimental period. Significant interactions between nano-Se and garlic oil on the ejaculate volume were found (P < 0.01), however, no significant interaction effect (P > 0.05) were observed on sperm livability. There was no significant effect (P > 0.05) of nano-Se, garlic oil, or their combination on semen pH value. Abnormal sperm percentage decreased (P < 0.01) in male rabbits fed the diets containing nano-Se and garlic oil, compared to their non-supplemented counterparts. However, there was a tendency (P=0.061) of significant interaction between nano-Se and garlic oil on abnormal sperm percentage (P > 0.05) in male Californian rabbits.

sections.heading: 3.4. Blood biochemical constituents
sections.text:
The effects of dietary supplemental nano-Se, garlic oil or their combination on the liver and kidney function tests as well as serum testosterone levels of male Californian rabbits is presented in Table 5. Rabbits fed the diets added with either nano-Se or garlic oil or their combination showed the lower (P < 0.001) serum levels of ALT and AST activities compared to the non-added groups. Likewise, serum urea nitrogen, urea, and creatinine decreased significantly (P < 0.05) with supplementation of nano-Se, garlic oil, or their combination to rabbits when compared to non-supplemented counterparts. On the other hand, there was no interaction effect
a−cMeans not sharing a common superscript in a row are significantly different (P<0.05). Means are average of twenty replicates (n= 20 animals per treatment) determined at the end of the experimental period (120–180 days of age). Nano-SE: Control with 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium, Garlic oil: Control with 700mg kg−1 garlic oil, nano-Se+Garlic oil: Control with combination of 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium+700mg kg−1 garlic oil. SEM: Standard error of the means.
a−c Means not sharing a common superscript in a row are significantly different (P< 0.05). Nano-SE: Control with 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium, Garlic oil: Control with 700mg kg−1 garlic oil, nano-Se+Garlic oil: Control with combination of 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium+700mg kg−1 garlic oil. Means are average of twenty replicates (n=20 animals per treatment) determined at the end of the experimental period (120–180 days of age). One ejaculate sample per animal was obtained. SEM: Standard error of the means.
on serum creatinine. Interestingly, concentrations of testosterone in the serum increased significantly (P < 0.05) in rabbits fed diets supplemented with nano-Se and garlic oil when compared to their non-supplemented counterparts, and an interaction effect was also observed showing synergistic effect of nano-Se and garlic oil on increasing serum testosterone levels.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
Selenium has important biological functions and is an essential element required for normal animal growth and reproduction by controlling the body’s energy, protein anabolism and oxidative stress (Surai, 2002; 2006; Preter, 2000; Zhang et al., 2011). Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Commercial premixes were used in the present study without supplemental Se. However, there are insufficient data in the literature to permit a sound recommendation for rabbits at different production ages and sex. For instance, NRC (1977) recommended about 0.08mg/kg Se is required in the basal diet of growing rabbit. Also, De Blas and Mateos (2010) reported that it is advisable to include a small amount of supplemental Se (0.05 mg/kg) in the feeds of rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of Se at 0.1 and 0.3 mg/kg to female New Zealand White rabbit’s diets had a positive effect on increasing the productive and reproductive performance (Strucklec et al., 1994). However, more recent research of Zhang et al. (2011) indicated that the Se content of the basal diet (0.08 mg/kg) failed to meet the growth requirements of meat rabbits from weaning to 2 months old and optimum growth performance and feed conversion ratio were achieved when the dietary Se level was 0.70mg/kg. Furthermore, body weight gain of rabbits increased significantly (P < 0.05) in groups supplemented with 0.6 mg sodium selenite/kg diet and 0.6 mg selenium yeast/kg diet compared with the control group at 8 weeks of age (Amer et al., 2018). Moreover, supplementation of linseed oil plus selenium (0.3mg/kg) to growing rabbit diet improved nutrient utilization significantly (Saleh et al., 2013). There are no clear recommendations for the appropriate amount of supplemental Se to be given to growing rabbits, hence, in the present study a slight increase in the required level at 0.66mg/kg based on basal diet ingredients plus 400 μg/kg supplemental nano-Se was used for male rabbits at 120 to 180 days of age.
In this study, rabbits supplemented with 400 μg/kg nano-Se and nano-Se combined with garlic oil had higher BW gain compared with the non-supplemented rabbits. This effect could be related to the ability of nano-Se alone or combined with garlic oil supplementation to improve nutrient digestibility (Table 3). Selenium and phytogenic supplementation have shown to possess antioxidant activities and improved digestion and absorption of dietary nutrients (Brenes and Roura, 2010; Mahima et al., 2012) that might have improved the performance and production efficiency of rabbits in this study, particularly in hot environments. Also, the greatest body weight gain and the smallest feed conversion ratio were observed in the rabbits fed with the diet of 0.70mg/kg Se (Zhang et al., 2011). Feed supplemented with selenium significantly increased bucks live body weight and feed intake and significantly decreased rectal temperature compared with control group (Kamel, 2012). Furthermore, body weight gain of rabbits increased significantly (P < 0.05) in groups supplemented with 0.6mg sodium selenite/kg diet and 0.6 mg selenium yeast/kg diet compared with the control group at 8 weeks of age (Amer et al., 2018). On the other hand, Papadomichelakis et al. (2017) reported that dietary Se supplementation did not have any effect on feed intake, growth rate and feed conversion ratio in growing rabbits. Likewise, the dietary inclusion of linseed oil and selenium did not provide significant differences among groups in terms of live weight, weight gain, feed intake and feed conversion ratio (Matics et al., 2017). Supplementation of different selenium sources had insignificant effects on the final body weight and daily weight gain of rabbits, however, significant (P≤ 0.05) decrease in feed intake and significant (P≤ 0.05) improvement in feed conversion ratio ranged from 11.5 to 19.4% due to different experimental treatments in comparison with the control one (Zeweil et al., 2016).
There is limited information regarding effects of nano-Se or Se sources on nutrient digestibility of rabbits. Nano-Se supplementation at 400 μg/kg of diet improved digestibility of DM, OM, CP, and CF in Californian male rabbits. This may increase the
a−b Means not sharing a common superscript in a row are significantly different (P<0.05). Nano-SE: Control with 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium, Garlic oil: Control with 700mg kg−1 garlic oil, nano-Se+Garlic oil: Control with combination of 400 μg kg−1 nano Selenium+700mg kg−1 garlic oil. Means are average of ten replicates (n= 10 animals per treatment) determined at the end of the experimental period (120–180 days of age). SEM: Standard error of the means. ALT: alanine aminotransferase. AST: aspartate aminotransferase.
ability of rabbits to overcome the effects of heat stress. The beneficial response of nutrient utilization may be due to the positive effects of Se as an antioxidant agent which protect nutrients from oxidation (Yang et al., 2012). These results are in agreement with those of Amer et al. (2018) who reported that there was significant increase (P < 0.05) in crude fiber digestibility of rabbits by 28% in groups supplemented with organic selenium compared to control group. Moreover, supplementation of linseed oil plus selenium (0.3mg/kg) to rabbit diet improved significantly protein digestibility and energy utilization to the extent of 20% and 11%, respectively, compared to control (Saleh et al., 2013). Fan et al. (2009) also found that supplementation of Se to broiler diet improved protein digestibility and energy utilization.
However, garlic oil supplementation also improved DM, OM, CP, EE, and CF digestibility in rabbits compared to non-supplemented group in our study. The interaction effects of nano-Se and garlic oil were observed on nutrients digestibility in the present study. Similarly, herbs and essential oils are incorporated into poultry diets to stimulate or promote a more effective use of feed nutrients, which may subsequently result in improving nutrient digestibility and performance (Hippenstiel et al., 2011). The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies.
Nano-Se exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility in the semen collected at the end of the experimental period. These improvements in semen quality may be related to improvements in body weight (Table 2) and testes weight (data not shown) due to nano-Se supplementation. Moreover, selenium improves the reproductive process and protection against oxidative stress by enhancing the semen quality and quantity (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016). Likewise, semen quality was significantly higher in rabbit bucks that received Vit. E and selenium than control rabbit bucks (Yaseen et al., 2016). Supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbits diets (120–150 days of age) improved their total sperm output to comparable levels of that observed in control old rabbits which could enhance their earlier usage in rabbit farms (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Furthermore, ejaculate volume, mass motility, sperm concentration, total sperm output, total motile sperms, live and normal sperm of rabbits were significantly increased when their diet was supplemented with Se compared to control group under heat stress conditions (Kamel, 2012).
In the present study, dietary addition of garlic oil to Californian male rabbits for 60 days increased the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility compared to non-added group. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats. Garlic juice (120mg/kg) improves sperm quality and quantity (Ghalehkandi et al., 2012) in parallel to our results. It seems that the positive effects of garlic oil on semen and sperm quality may be via antioxidant defense mechanisms such as regulation of cytochrome P450 enzymes (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Garlic oil has an antioxidant activity which may be due to its active compounds (Kim et al., 2013).
In the present study, dietary supplementation of nano-Se decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity, as well as increased serum testosterone levels compared to non-supplemented group. These results suggest that feeding a diet supplemented with nano-Se might improve liver and kidney functions in rabbits, consequently alleviating the adverse effects of high ambient temperature. These results agree with those of Kamel (2012) which reported that seminal plasma aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase were significantly decreased in rabbit fed diet supplemented with Se, folic acid and their combinations compared to the control group. Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increases observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium levels and could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbit’s diets (120–150 days of age) did not affect blood biochemical parameters of rabbits (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Selenium can enhance the testosterone production which could be closely related to the regulating roles of Se in male fertility and spermatogenesis (Shi et al., 2017). Dietary supplementation of garlic oil decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity compared to non-garlic-added groups in this study. Results obtained herein agree with those of Alagawany et al. (2016) where supplementation of diets with garlic and turmeric decreased ALT and AST in rabbit serum compared with the control group, suggesting the hepato-protective effect of supplementation.
Interestingly, in the present study results showed that serum testosterone concentration was increased in rabbits fed diet supplemented with garlic oil. This may be due to the significant increase in testes weight (data not shown) and that garlic oil could have reduced negative effects of high temperatures as observed in this study. Likewise, increased testes size has been shown to positively correlate to an increase in testosterone production with subsequent improvement in semen production (Bailey et al., 1996). These results agree with El-Gogary et al. (2017) which reported that testosterone level in rabbits was significantly higher for garlic oil treatments compared to the control group. Also, Oi et al. (2001) found that garlic administration increases testosterone production in rats.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In view of the above findings, it can be concluded that dietary nano-Se at 400 μg/kg, garlic oil at 700mg/kg, or their combination resulted in improved nutrient digestibility, liver and kidney functions, as well as semen quality, indicating a possible synergistic effect of nano-Se and garlic oil in improving these parameters.
Declaration of interest
The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors are thankful for the research funds from South Valley University, Egypt for supporting this project.

referenceMentions.context: In North African countries rabbit industry has developed rapidly, and applied research on vital aspects of rabbit production such as economics, housing, management, nutrition and reproduction is urgently needed to ensure a high success rate of rabbit development, which could have a favorable economic and nutritional impact (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2015; Al-Sagheer et al., 2017).

With the use of nanotechnology, nanoparticles can be used as a supplemental source of trace minerals in the diets which have been found to have several novel properties different to those from bulk materials or commercial salts of these minerals (Mohapatra et al., 2014).

Dietary selenium is an essential trace element for animal growth, fertility, hormones, physiological parameters and metabolism as well as external and internal organs (Mohapatra et al., 2014; Surai, 2006).

Dietary selenium is an essential trace element for animal growth, fertility, hormones, physiological parameters and metabolism as well as external and internal organs (Mohapatra et al., 2014; Surai, 2006).
Selenium improves the productive performance and antioxidant status of animals, particularly in hot summer environments (Mahima et al., 2012).

The feed additives like nanoparticles of trace minerals, herbal plants, essential oils, probiotics, and enzymes play an active role in productive and reproductive performance of domestic animals (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Abdel-Wareth and Lohakare, 2014; Ashour et al., 2014).

The feed additives like nanoparticles of trace minerals, herbal plants, essential oils, probiotics, and enzymes play an active role in productive and reproductive performance of domestic animals (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Abdel-Wareth and Lohakare, 2014; Ashour et al., 2014).
However, commercial premixes without supplemental selenium have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004).

, 2012; Abdel-Wareth and Lohakare, 2014; Ashour et al., 2014). Since ancient times, garlic (Allium sativum L.) has been used to cure diseases. The first citation of medical application of garlic as a remedy is found in the Codex Ebers (1550 BCE), an Egyptian medical papyrus (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Supplementation of garlic oil at 0.5 g/kg of diet has a positive effect on testes weight, antioxidant status, and testosterone hormone in rabbits (El-Gogary et al., 2017). Alagawany et al. (2016) reported that garlic improved the immunity responses and lowered the lipid profile in blood, lipid peroxidation in liver, and increased hepatic antioxidant activity in treated rabbits.

, 2012; Abdel-Wareth and Lohakare, 2014; Ashour et al., 2014). Since ancient times, garlic (Allium sativum L.) has been used to cure diseases. The first citation of medical application of garlic as a remedy is found in the Codex Ebers (1550 BCE), an Egyptian medical papyrus (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Supplementation of garlic oil at 0.5 g/kg of diet has a positive effect on testes weight, antioxidant status, and testosterone hormone in rabbits (El-Gogary et al., 2017). Alagawany et al. (2016) reported that garlic improved the immunity responses and lowered the lipid profile in blood, lipid peroxidation in liver, and increased hepatic antioxidant activity in treated rabbits. The major bioactive components in garlic such as Allicin are mainly responsible for the positive effects of garlic (Santhosha et al., 2013). Productive and reproductive performances as well as physiological parameters were improved significantly by addition of garlic powder to rabbit diet (Onu and Aja, 2011). Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increase observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium level could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits.

Throughout the trial, the rabbits were handled according to the principles of the care of experimental animals (Lebas et al., 1984), and the experiment was approved by the Committee of Ethics of the Animal and Poultry Production Department of the South Valley University. During the experiment, rabbits were subjected to regular inspections for body condition and health. The assessments of body condition were carried out by touching the ribs, pelvis, and spine of the rabbits. A completely randomized design was used for investigating effects of nano-Se, garlic oil and their combination. A total of 80 male Californian rabbits (average body weight 2062 ± 12 g, 120 days old) were randomly distributed into four treatment groups of 20 rabbits each. Treatment groups were fed a control diet (Table 1), a control diet supplemented with nano-Se (400 μg/kg), control diet supplemented with garlic oil (700mg/kg), or control diet supplemented with combination of nano-selenium (400 μg/kg) and garlic oil (700mg/kg). The diets were formulated according to the requirements of growing rabbit recommended by NRC (1977). Ingredients, chemical composition and the energy value of the experimental diets are presented in Table 1.

Throughout the trial, the rabbits were handled according to the principles of the care of experimental animals (Lebas et al., 1984), and the experiment was approved by the Committee of Ethics of the Animal and Poultry Production Department of the South Valley University. During the experiment, rabbits were subjected to regular inspections for body condition and health. The assessments of body condition were carried out by touching the ribs, pelvis, and spine of the rabbits. A completely randomized design was used for investigating effects of nano-Se, garlic oil and their combination. A total of 80 male Californian rabbits (average body weight 2062 ± 12 g, 120 days old) were randomly distributed into four treatment groups of 20 rabbits each. Treatment groups were fed a control diet (Table 1), a control diet supplemented with nano-Se (400 μg/kg), control diet supplemented with garlic oil (700mg/kg), or control diet supplemented with combination of nano-selenium (400 μg/kg) and garlic oil (700mg/kg). The diets were formulated according to the requirements of growing rabbit recommended by NRC (1977). Ingredients, chemical composition and the energy value of the experimental diets are presented in Table 1. During the whole experiment, animals of all treatments received the pelleted diet for ad libitum consumption. First, Nano-Se, garlic oil or their combination were mixed separately in 2 kg of the basal diet each and then they were added to the required feed amount for the prescribed experimental period. The vitamin-mineral premix did not contain Se. Se content of the basal diet was analyzed (Agilent technologies, 8800 ICP-MS Triple Quad, Germany) and shown in Table 1. The major components of garlic oil were extracted by Clevenger-type laboratory distillation according to Satyal et al. (2017). The main components of garlic oil were diallyl trisulfide (allitridin, 33%), diallyl disulfide (21%), allyl methyl trisulfide (19%), allyl (E)-1propenyl disulfide (5%), and allyl methyl disulfide (4%).
When an interaction effect was found the differences between treatments means were distinguished by Duncans multiple range test (Duncan, 1955).
Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004).
3 mg/kg to female New Zealand White rabbit’s diets had a positive effect on increasing the productive and reproductive performance (Strucklec et al., 1994).

Selenium and phytogenic supplementation have shown to possess antioxidant activities and improved digestion and absorption of dietary nutrients (Brenes and Roura, 2010; Mahima et al., 2012) that might have improved the performance and production efficiency of rabbits in this study, particularly in hot environments.

Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Commercial premixes were used in the present study without supplemental Se. However, there are insufficient data in the literature to permit a sound recommendation for rabbits at different production ages and sex. For instance, NRC (1977) recommended about 0.

Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Commercial premixes were used in the present study without supplemental Se. However, there are insufficient data in the literature to permit a sound recommendation for rabbits at different production ages and sex. For instance, NRC (1977) recommended about 0.08mg/kg Se is required in the basal diet of growing rabbit. Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Commercial premixes were used in the present study without supplemental Se. However, there are insufficient data in the literature to permit a sound recommendation for rabbits at different production ages and sex. For instance, NRC (1977) recommended about 0.08mg/kg Se is required in the basal diet of growing rabbit. Also, De Blas and Mateos (2010) reported that it is advisable to include a small amount of supplemental Se (0.05 mg/kg) in the feeds of rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of Se at 0.1 and 0.3 mg/kg to female New Zealand White rabbit’s diets had a positive effect on increasing the productive and reproductive performance (Strucklec et al., 1994). However, more recent research of Zhang et al. (2011) indicated that the Se content of the basal diet (0.

Commercial premixes without supplemental Se have been marketed for years in Europe without any evidence of impaired productivity in does or in growing-fattening rabbits (Lebas, 2004). Commercial premixes were used in the present study without supplemental Se. However, there are insufficient data in the literature to permit a sound recommendation for rabbits at different production ages and sex. For instance, NRC (1977) recommended about 0.08mg/kg Se is required in the basal diet of growing rabbit. Also, De Blas and Mateos (2010) reported that it is advisable to include a small amount of supplemental Se (0.05 mg/kg) in the feeds of rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of Se at 0.1 and 0.3 mg/kg to female New Zealand White rabbit’s diets had a positive effect on increasing the productive and reproductive performance (Strucklec et al., 1994). However, more recent research of Zhang et al. (2011) indicated that the Se content of the basal diet (0.08 mg/kg) failed to meet the growth requirements of meat rabbits from weaning to 2 months old and optimum growth performance and feed conversion ratio were achieved when the dietary Se level was 0.70mg/kg. Furthermore, body weight gain of rabbits increased significantly (P < 0.05) in groups supplemented with 0.6 mg sodium selenite/kg diet and 0.6 mg selenium yeast/kg diet compared with the control group at 8 weeks of age (Amer et al., 2018). Moreover, supplementation of linseed oil plus selenium (0.3mg/kg) to growing rabbit diet improved nutrient utilization significantly (Saleh et al., 2013). There are no clear recommendations for the appropriate amount of supplemental Se to be given to growing rabbits, hence, in the present study a slight increase in the required level at 0.66mg/kg based on basal diet ingredients plus 400 μg/kg supplemental nano-Se was used for male rabbits at 120 to 180 days of age. In this study, rabbits supplemented with 400 μg/kg nano-Se and nano-Se combined with garlic oil had higher BW gain compared with the non-supplemented rabbits. This effect could be related to the ability of nano-Se alone or combined with garlic oil supplementation to improve nutrient digestibility (Table 3). Selenium and phytogenic supplementation have shown to possess antioxidant activities and improved digestion and absorption of dietary nutrients (Brenes and Roura, 2010; Mahima et al., 2012) that might have improved the performance and production efficiency of rabbits in this study, particularly in hot environments. Also, the greatest body weight gain and the smallest feed conversion ratio were observed in the rabbits fed with the diet of 0.70mg/kg Se (Zhang et al., 2011). Feed supplemented with selenium significantly increased bucks live body weight and feed intake and significantly decreased rectal temperature compared with control group (Kamel, 2012). Furthermore, body weight gain of rabbits increased significantly (P < 0.05) in groups supplemented with 0.6mg sodium selenite/kg diet and 0.6 mg selenium yeast/kg diet compared with the control group at 8 weeks of age (Amer et al., 2018). On the other hand, Papadomichelakis et al. (2017) reported that dietary Se supplementation did not have any effect on feed intake, growth rate and feed conversion ratio in growing rabbits.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010).
Selenium can enhance the testosterone production which could be closely related to the regulating roles of Se in male fertility and spermatogenesis (Shi et al., 2017).
Fan et al. (2009) also found that supplementation of Se to broiler diet improved protein digestibility and energy utilization.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. Nano-Se exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility in the semen collected at the end of the experimental period. These improvements in semen quality may be related to improvements in body weight (Table 2) and testes weight (data not shown) due to nano-Se supplementation. Moreover, selenium improves the reproductive process and protection against oxidative stress by enhancing the semen quality and quantity (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016). Likewise, semen quality was significantly higher in rabbit bucks that received Vit. E and selenium than control rabbit bucks (Yaseen et al., 2016). Supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbits diets (120–150 days of age) improved their total sperm output to comparable levels of that observed in control old rabbits which could enhance their earlier usage in rabbit farms (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Furthermore, ejaculate volume, mass motility, sperm concentration, total sperm output, total motile sperms, live and normal sperm of rabbits were significantly increased when their diet was supplemented with Se compared to control group under heat stress conditions (Kamel, 2012). In the present study, dietary addition of garlic oil to Californian male rabbits for 60 days increased the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility compared to non-added group. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. Nano-Se exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility in the semen collected at the end of the experimental period. These improvements in semen quality may be related to improvements in body weight (Table 2) and testes weight (data not shown) due to nano-Se supplementation. Moreover, selenium improves the reproductive process and protection against oxidative stress by enhancing the semen quality and quantity (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016). Likewise, semen quality was significantly higher in rabbit bucks that received Vit. E and selenium than control rabbit bucks (Yaseen et al., 2016). Supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbits diets (120–150 days of age) improved their total sperm output to comparable levels of that observed in control old rabbits which could enhance their earlier usage in rabbit farms (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Furthermore, ejaculate volume, mass motility, sperm concentration, total sperm output, total motile sperms, live and normal sperm of rabbits were significantly increased when their diet was supplemented with Se compared to control group under heat stress conditions (Kamel, 2012). In the present study, dietary addition of garlic oil to Californian male rabbits for 60 days increased the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility compared to non-added group. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats. Garlic juice (120mg/kg) improves sperm quality and quantity (Ghalehkandi et al., 2012) in parallel to our results. It seems that the positive effects of garlic oil on semen and sperm quality may be via antioxidant defense mechanisms such as regulation of cytochrome P450 enzymes (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Garlic oil has an antioxidant activity which may be due to its active compounds (Kim et al., 2013). In the present study, dietary supplementation of nano-Se decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity, as well as increased serum testosterone levels compared to non-supplemented group. These results suggest that feeding a diet supplemented with nano-Se might improve liver and kidney functions in rabbits, consequently alleviating the adverse effects of high ambient temperature. These results agree with those of Kamel (2012) which reported that seminal plasma aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase were significantly decreased in rabbit fed diet supplemented with Se, folic acid and their combinations compared to the control group.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats. It seems that the positive effects of garlic oil on semen and sperm quality may be via antioxidant defense mechanisms such as regulation of cytochrome P450 enzymes (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Garlic oil has an antioxidant activity which may be due to its active compounds (Kim et al., 2013). These results agree with those of Kamel (2012) which reported that seminal plasma aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase were significantly decreased in rabbit fed diet supplemented with Se, folic acid and their combinations compared to the control group. Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increases observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium levels and could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. Nano-Se exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility in the semen collected at the end of the experimental period. These improvements in semen quality may be related to improvements in body weight (Table 2) and testes weight (data not shown) due to nano-Se supplementation. Moreover, selenium improves the reproductive process and protection against oxidative stress by enhancing the semen quality and quantity (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016). Likewise, semen quality was significantly higher in rabbit bucks that received Vit. E and selenium than control rabbit bucks (Yaseen et al., 2016). Supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbits diets (120–150 days of age) improved their total sperm output to comparable levels of that observed in control old rabbits which could enhance their earlier usage in rabbit farms (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Furthermore, ejaculate volume, mass motility, sperm concentration, total sperm output, total motile sperms, live and normal sperm of rabbits were significantly increased when their diet was supplemented with Se compared to control group under heat stress conditions (Kamel, 2012). In the present study, dietary addition of garlic oil to Californian male rabbits for 60 days increased the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility compared to non-added group. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats. Garlic juice (120mg/kg) improves sperm quality and quantity (Ghalehkandi et al., 2012) in parallel to our results. It seems that the positive effects of garlic oil on semen and sperm quality may be via antioxidant defense mechanisms such as regulation of cytochrome P450 enzymes (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Garlic oil has an antioxidant activity which may be due to its active compounds (Kim et al., 2013). In the present study, dietary supplementation of nano-Se decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity, as well as increased serum testosterone levels compared to non-supplemented group. These results suggest that feeding a diet supplemented with nano-Se might improve liver and kidney functions in rabbits, consequently alleviating the adverse effects of high ambient temperature. These results agree with those of Kamel (2012) which reported that seminal plasma aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase were significantly decreased in rabbit fed diet supplemented with Se, folic acid and their combinations compared to the control group. Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increases observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium levels and could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbit’s diets (120–150 days of age) did not affect blood biochemical parameters of rabbits (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Selenium can enhance the testosterone production which could be closely related to the regulating roles of Se in male fertility and spermatogenesis (Shi et al., 2017). Dietary supplementation of garlic oil decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity compared to non-garlic-added groups in this study. Results obtained herein agree with those of Alagawany et al. (2016) where supplementation of diets with garlic and turmeric decreased ALT and AST in rabbit serum compared with the control group, suggesting the hepato-protective effect of supplementation.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. Nano-Se exhibited a significant increase in the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility in the semen collected at the end of the experimental period. These improvements in semen quality may be related to improvements in body weight (Table 2) and testes weight (data not shown) due to nano-Se supplementation. Moreover, selenium improves the reproductive process and protection against oxidative stress by enhancing the semen quality and quantity (Abdulrashid and Juniper, 2016). Likewise, semen quality was significantly higher in rabbit bucks that received Vit. E and selenium than control rabbit bucks (Yaseen et al., 2016). Supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbits diets (120–150 days of age) improved their total sperm output to comparable levels of that observed in control old rabbits which could enhance their earlier usage in rabbit farms (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Furthermore, ejaculate volume, mass motility, sperm concentration, total sperm output, total motile sperms, live and normal sperm of rabbits were significantly increased when their diet was supplemented with Se compared to control group under heat stress conditions (Kamel, 2012). In the present study, dietary addition of garlic oil to Californian male rabbits for 60 days increased the ejaculate volume, sperm livability, and sperm motility compared to non-added group. These results agree with those of Kasuga et al. (2001) that reported garlic has positive effects in testicular functions and spermatogenesis in rats. Garlic juice (120mg/kg) improves sperm quality and quantity (Ghalehkandi et al., 2012) in parallel to our results. It seems that the positive effects of garlic oil on semen and sperm quality may be via antioxidant defense mechanisms such as regulation of cytochrome P450 enzymes (Ghalehkandi, 2014). Garlic oil has an antioxidant activity which may be due to its active compounds (Kim et al., 2013). In the present study, dietary supplementation of nano-Se decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity, as well as increased serum testosterone levels compared to non-supplemented group. These results suggest that feeding a diet supplemented with nano-Se might improve liver and kidney functions in rabbits, consequently alleviating the adverse effects of high ambient temperature. These results agree with those of Kamel (2012) which reported that seminal plasma aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase were significantly decreased in rabbit fed diet supplemented with Se, folic acid and their combinations compared to the control group. Olisekodiaka et al. (2015) reported that significant increases observed in the activities of antioxidant enzymes and selenium levels and could possibly be associated with consumption of high garlic diet by the rabbits. On the other hand, supplementation of vitamin E and selenium to rabbit’s diets (120–150 days of age) did not affect blood biochemical parameters of rabbits (El-Azzazi et al., 2016). Selenium can enhance the testosterone production which could be closely related to the regulating roles of Se in male fertility and spermatogenesis (Shi et al., 2017). Dietary supplementation of garlic oil decreased serum urea, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, ALT and AST activity compared to non-garlic-added groups in this study. Results obtained herein agree with those of Alagawany et al. (2016) where supplementation of diets with garlic and turmeric decreased ALT and AST in rabbit serum compared with the control group, suggesting the hepato-protective effect of supplementation. Interestingly, in the present study results showed that serum testosterone concentration was increased in rabbits fed diet supplemented with garlic oil. This may be due to the significant increase in testes weight (data not shown) and that garlic oil could have reduced negative effects of high temperatures as observed in this study. Likewise, increased testes size has been shown to positively correlate to an increase in testosterone production with subsequent improvement in semen production (Bailey et al., 1996). These results agree with El-Gogary et al. (2017) which reported that testosterone level in rabbits was significantly higher for garlic oil treatments compared to the control group.

The beneficial effects of dietary inclusion of phytogenics on growth performance, gut health, digestion of nutrients, and intestinal integrity has been reported earlier (Abdel-Wareth et al., 2012; Brenes and Roura, 2010). These beneficial effects might be directly associated with improvements in performance in some of those studies. Interestingly, in the present study results showed that serum testosterone concentration was increased in rabbits fed diet supplemented with garlic oil. This may be due to the significant increase in testes weight (data not shown) and that garlic oil could have reduced negative effects of high temperatures as observed in this study. Likewise, increased testes size has been shown to positively correlate to an increase in testosterone production with subsequent improvement in semen production (Bailey et al., 1996). These results agree with El-Gogary et al. (2017) which reported that testosterone level in rabbits was significantly higher for garlic oil treatments compared to the control group. Also, Oi et al. (2001) found that garlic administration increases testosterone production in rats.

metadata.abstractText: This study aimed to investigate the effects of nano-selenium (nano-Se), garlic oil, and their combination on nutrients digestibility, semen quality, serum testosterone and metabolites of male Californian rabbits. A total of 80 rabbits (120 days of age) were randomly distributed into four treatment groups of 20 rabbits each. Treatment groups were fed a control diet, a control diet supplemented with nano-Se (400 μg/kg), control diet supplemented with garlic oil (700mg/kg), or control diet supplemented with combination of nano-Se (400 μg/kg) and garlic oil (700mg/ kg). The feeding trial lasted for 60 days. The results showed that improvements were observed in body weight (BW) gain and feed conversion ratio (FCR) in nano-Se treated group than nonsupplemented group, and an interaction effect was observed on final BW of rabbits. The digestibility of all measured nutrients were significantly higher (P < 0.01) for animals fed nanoSe, garlic oil, and the combination group compared to their non-supplemented counterparts. Furthermore, semen characteristics were significantly improved (P < 0.01) in nano-Se and garlic oil supplemented groups compared to non-supplemented groups. Likewise, supplementation of nano-Se, garlic oil, and their combination significantly improved liver and kidney functions as indicated from serum metabolites, and increased serum testosterone hormone levels. Therefore, it can be concluded that nano-Se or garlic oil and their combination improved the nutrients digestibility, semen quality, kidney and liver functions, and testosterone levels in male rabbits. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.anifeedsci.2019.01.016 Received 17 April 2018; Received in revised form 4 January 2019; Accepted 28 January 2019 Abbreviations: nano-Se, nano-selenium; BW, body weight; FCR, feed conversion ratio; AST, aspartate transaminase; ALT, alanine transaminase; BUN, blood urea nitrogen; DM, dry matter; OM, organic matter; CP, crude protein; EE, ether extract; CF, crude fiber ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Agriculture Animal Science, University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, Pine Bluff, AR, 71601, USA. E-mail address: lohakarej@uapb.edu (J. Lohakare). Animal Feed Science and Technology 249 (2019) 37–45 0377-8401/ Published by Elsevier B.V. T
metadata.creator: Elsevier
